Date Range of Study: Two scenarios; 1 and 2 X CO2 emissions climate scenarios
Study Area: 764 stream gaging stations in the contiguous United States of America
Detailed Change in Response Variable: decrease for cool water fish based on 0 degree minimum tempeature tolerance but slight increase based on 2 degree temperature tolerance
Freshwater Ecoregion: Alaska & Canada Pacific Coastal; English - Winnipeg Lakes; Laurentian Great Lakes; St. Lawrence; Northeast US & Southeast Canada Atlantic Drainages; Columbia Glaciated; Columbia Unglaciated; Upper Snake; Oregon & Northern California Coastal; Oregon Lakes; Sacramento - San Joaquin; Lahontan; Bonneville; Death Valley; Vegas - Virgin; Colorado; Upper Rio Grande - Bravo; Lower Rio Grande - Bravo; West Texas Gulf; East Texas Gulf; Sabine - Galveston; Upper Missouri; Middle Missouri; US Southern Plains; Ouachita Highlands; Central Prairie; Ozark Highlands; Upper Mississippi; Lower Mississippi; Teays - Old Ohio; Cumberland; Tennessee; Mobile Bay; West Florida Gulf; Apalachicola; Florida Peninsula; Appalachian Piedmont; Chesapeake Bay; Southern California Coastal - Baja California
Major Habitat Type: Large lakes; Temperate coastal rivers; Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands; Temperate upland rivers; Tropical and subtropical coastal rivers; Xeric freshwaters and endorheic (closed) basins
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Management decisions regarding stocking of streams and fishing regulations to accommodate declines or increases
Management Recommendations: Alter stocking practices; Modify fishing regulations
Reviewer Comments: The authors found both a decrease and increase in range of coolwater species depending on the temperature tolerance the authors used to analyze the data. They presented both results and mentioned that 0 degree C tolerance may too low, but that the 0 degree C tolerance was most likely more representative than the 2 degree tolerance, so is what we reported here.

Reviewer Comments: The authors found both a decrease and increase in range of coolwater species depending on the temperature tolerance the authors used to analyze the data. They presented both results and mentioned that 0 degree C tolerance may too low, but that the 0 degree C tolerance was most likely more representative than the 2 degree tolerance, so is what we reported here.

Date Range of Study: Varies; 15 to 25 year time frame from 1979-2003
Study Area: Rhone, Loire, and Seine Rivers, France
Freshwater Ecoregion: Central & Western Europe
Management Recommendations - Detailed: No formal management recommendation
Reviewer Comments: Assemblage composition: (1) Species with high affinity for high temperatures (tench Tinca tinca, bream Abramis brama, white bream Blicca bjoerkna,rudd Scardinius erythrophthalmusL, wels catfish Silurus glanis, and black bullhead Ameiurus melas. (2) Species with medium affinity for high temperatures (Bleak Alburnus alburnus, stream bleak Alburnoides bipunctatus, barbel Barbus barbus,chub Leuciscus cephalus, roach Rutilus rutilus and bitterling Rhodeus sericeusP. (3) Species with low affinity for high temperatures (pike Esox lucius, perch Perca fluviatilis, pumpkinseed Lepomis gibbosus, gudgeon Gobiogobio, nase Chondrostoma nasus and dace Leucis-cus leuciscus.

Reviewer Comments: Distribution of 132 species were modeled.

Detailed Change in Response Variable: declines with warming, ameliorated by groundwater contribution
Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Prevent thermal stress on priorized watersheds by: limiting ground and suface water withdrawals, increasing forest canopy and riparian cover, regulate urban development to minimize effects on water quality and quantity.  Prioritized watersheds will vary if consider managing for short or long term goals. Long-term would suggest prioritize protection of resilient (high groundwater contribution to baseflow) streams
Management Recommendations: Manage flows; Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats; Minimize other anthropogenic stressors; Prioritize populations based on vulnerability; Protect refugial populations and/or habitats

Study Area: South Fork Trinity River, California, United States of America
Freshwater Ecoregion: Oregon & Northern California Coastal
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "Forest practices that maximize riparian vegetation shading to reduce solar input and increase allochthonous prey input may keep streams closer to the optimal temperature for O. mykiss growth as well as provide greater nutritional benefits for stream-dwelling salmonids."
Management Recommendations: Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats

Study Area: Piedmont headwater streams of Chesapeake Bay
Detailed Change in Response Variable: Climate change depressed growth or reproduction in 22 to 29 species of 39 speces. The effect of climate change was often magnified by the presence of increased urbanization.
Freshwater Ecoregion: Chesapeake Bay
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "Proactive and reactive management actions may enable society to adapt to climate change, but reactive management may cost more because of damage to infrastructure such as roads or bridges; proactive approaches such as increasing stormwater management to reduce peak flows and temperature stress in developed basins, or preferably, acquiring land near streams to free floodplains of infrastructure, thereby allowing re-growth of riparian vegetation. Where land is not already heavily developed, land preservation programmes could be used to protect headwater streams. More aggressive efforts to reduce sediment and pollutant loads, including the use of staging during construction and establishing vegetative buffers along streams and roads would also reduce the stresses on stream biota.
Management Recommendations: Manage flows; Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats; Protect refugial populations and/or habitats; Minimize other anthropogenic stressors

Climate Change Driver: climate change scenarios coupled with smallmouth bass expansion
Detailed Change in Response Variable: increase in vulnerability of lake trout populations (11% of lake trout populaltions vulnerable to smallmouth bass invasions under climate change and increase from 1% to 20% vulnerability of lake trout populations)
Freshwater Ecoregion: Southern Hudson Bay
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Protect smaller lakes, education to reduce unwanted introductions, reduce sampling bias toward game species
Management Recommendations: Protect refugial populations and/or habitats; Prioritize populations based on vulnerability; Conduct research and/or monitoring; Education and outreach

Date Range of Study: Scenario of 3 degree Celsius increase to mean July air temperatures (1971-2000), 3 degree increase in average winter air temperatures, and increased likelihood of uncharacteristic fires
Study Area: Bonneville and Colorado River basins mostly in Utah, Colorado, Wyoming (also in Idaho, New Mexico, Arizona), United States of America
Freshwater Ecoregion: Bonneville; Colorado
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Increase habitat availability and quality; improve instream flows, remove barriers, limit livestock grazing, road development, and water withdrawals, alternatively, managers could isolate population with instream barriers to prevent downstream introduced salmonids
Management Recommendations: Manage flows; Restore connectivity; Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats; Minimize other anthropogenic stressors

Study Area: Rivers Derwent, Swale, Ure, Nidd, Wharfe, Ouse and Trent
Climate Change Driver: increased prevalence of warm-and-wet summers (River discharge for a given temperature)
Freshwater Ecoregion: Central & Western Europe
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "need for sympathetic management, particularly in relation to flood alleviation schemes, and, where possible, rehabilitation of floodplain ecosystems. Hydrological connectivity between rivers and their tributaries and flood plains is essential for the natural functioning of river ecosystems...Connection of relict channels or man-made waterbodies to rivers has the potential to augment riverine fish populations where natural river-floodplain connectivity has been lost, by providing spawning and nursery habitats, higher water temperatures and availability of planktonic food resources compared with main river channels, and refuge from floods (Nunn et al., 2007c). In-channel habitat features, such as backwaters and areas of submerged or emergent macrophytes, should also be managed sympathetically."
Management Recommendations: Manage flows; Restore connectivity; Protect refugial populations and/or habitats; Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats
Reviewer Comments: Considered variable recruitment to be negative for species.

Freshwater Ecoregion: English - Winnipeg Lakes; Upper Mississippi; Laurentian Great Lakes; Middle Missouri
Major Habitat Type: Large lakes; Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Further research investigating lake and river characteristics to identify factors that could be influencing the relationship between the timing of walleye spawning and ice-out, which would be useful for developing models that predict the timing of walleye spawning.

Date Range of Study: 2030 median lake areas under B-1 climate scenario
Freshwater Ecoregion: Murray - Darling
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "policies and practices governing river flow and lake level management need to be adaptable to reflect new scientific findings and the reality of a warmer and drier environment"

Date Range of Study: Four climate scenarios (Lake Erie current climate, Lake Erie 100-year projection, Lake Superior current climate, Lake Superior 100-year projection); Increase in surface temperature of 5-6 degrees Celsius from current conditions
Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes
Management Recommendations - Detailed: No formal management recommendation
Reviewer Comments: Growth was highest in the colder temperature scenarios. Authors found summer temperature to be the limiting factor to lake trout growth. Winter temperatures also played a factor in the lake trout growth for the higher temperature scenarios.

Date Range of Study: Four climate scenarios (Lake Erie current climate, Lake Erie 100-year projection, Lake Superior current climate, Lake Superior 100-year projection); Increase in surface temperature of 5-6 degrees Celsius from current conditions
Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes
Management Recommendations - Detailed: No formal management recommendation
Reviewer Comments: The degree of increase in growth of mottled sculpin varied with the the four climate scenarios . Authors found growth to be higher in the colder climate projection. Differences may depend on maximum summer temperature under the different scenarios as summer temperature highs had the greatest impact on growth. Authors also found an increase in bioaccumulation with increasing growth.

Date Range of Study: Four climate scenarios (Lake Erie current climate, Lake Erie 100-year projection, Lake Superior current climate, Lake Superior 100-year projection); Increase in surface temperature of 5-6 degrees Celsius from current conditions
Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes
Management Recommendations - Detailed: No formal management recommendation
Reviewer Comments: The degree of increase in growth of round goby varied with the the four climate scenarios. Authors found growth to be lowest in the colder climate scenario. Differences may depend on winter lows under the different scenarios as winter temperature had the greatest impact on growth. Authors also found an increase in bioaccumulation with increasing growth.

Date Range of Study: 2 degree Celsius increase in lake temperature
Study Area: Wood River System, Alaska, United States of America
Freshwater Ecoregion: Alaskan Coastal
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Manage system to retain population richness

Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Mitigation of climate change through decreased greenhouse gas emissions, slowing the rate of warming to reduce cisco extirpations, increase regulations and public education to reduce the spread of introduced rainbow smelt into Wisconsin lakes, and integrate lake watershed protection efforts with management to enhance water quality in lakes by decreasing nutrient loads and increasing hypolimnetic oxygen concentration
Management Recommendations: Education and outreach; Modify fishing regulations; Minimize other anthropogenic stressors; Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats
Reviewer Comments: Great example of incorporating specific management strategies to address climate change impacts - other potential management recommendation - stop climate change.

Country: Aland Islands, Albania, Andorra, Austria, Belarus, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Faroe Islands, Finland, France, Germany, Gibraltar, Greece, Guernsey, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Isle of Man, Italy, Jersey, Kosovo, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Macedonia, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, San Marino, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Svalbard and Jan Mayen, Sweden, Switzerland, Ukraine, United Kingdom
Freshwater Ecoregion: Central & Western Europe; Northern Baltic Drainages; Norwegian Sea Drainages; Northern British Isles; Cantabric Coast - Languedoc; Eastern Iberia; Western Iberia; Southern Iberia; Gulf of Venice Drainages; Dniester - Lower Danube; Italian Peninsula & Islands; Dnieper - South Bug; Southern Baltic Lowlands; Thrace; Vardar; Ionian Drainages; Western Anatolia; Aegean Drainages
Major Habitat Type: Polar freshwaters; Temperate coastal rivers; Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "Protected area planning will need to allow for, and to facilitate, species dispersal to more suitable habitats as environmental conditions change"; "a static approach to species conservation, where protected areas are positioned and managed under the assumption that conditions within them will remain suitable and that species will remain where they are today, is unlikely to be sufficient." Potential options: designatiton of new protected areas / reclassification of existing ones; enabling species movement across natural and artificial barriers (e.g., assisted colonization)
Management Recommendations: Restore connectivity; Protect refugial populations and/or habitats

Detailed Change in Response Variable: decrease 100% of range; no suitable catchments in Europe
Country: Aland Islands, Albania, Andorra, Austria, Belarus, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Faroe Islands, Finland, France, Germany, Gibraltar, Greece, Guernsey, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Isle of Man, Italy, Jersey, Kosovo, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Macedonia, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, San Marino, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Svalbard and Jan Mayen, Sweden, Switzerland, Ukraine, United Kingdom
Freshwater Ecoregion: Central & Western Europe; Northern Baltic Drainages; Norwegian Sea Drainages; Northern British Isles; Cantabric Coast - Languedoc; Eastern Iberia; Western Iberia; Southern Iberia; Gulf of Venice Drainages; Dniester - Lower Danube; Italian Peninsula & Islands; Dnieper - South Bug; Southern Baltic Lowlands; Thrace; Vardar; Ionian Drainages; Western Anatolia; Aegean Drainages
Major Habitat Type: Polar freshwaters; Temperate coastal rivers; Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "Protected area planning will need to allow for, and to facilitate, species dispersal to more suitable habitats as environmental conditions change"; "a static approach to species conservation, where protected areas are positioned and managed under the assumption that conditions within them will remain suitable and that species will remain where they are today, is unlikely to be sufficient." Potential options: designatiton of new protected areas / reclassification of existing ones; enabling species movement across natural and artificial barriers (e.g., assisted colonization)
Management Recommendations: Restore connectivity; Protect refugial populations and/or habitats

Management Recommendations - Detailed: "these correlations are considered in the context of temperature-dependent spawning migrations, our results indicate that in cool years, when female Striped Bass moved onto the spawning grounds later, more females were caught in the fishery before they could spawn. This result provides some basis for adjusting the dates of the trophy fishery to reduce the temperature-dependent effects of fishing mortality...these correlations are considered in the context of temperature-dependent spawning migrations, our results indicate that in cool years, when female Striped Bass moved onto the spawning grounds later, more females were caught in the fishery before they could spawn. This result provides some basis for adjusting the dates of the trophy fishery to reduce the temperature-dependent effects of fishing mortality."

Freshwater Ecoregion: Eastern Hudson Bay - Ungava; Gulf of St. Lawrence Coastal Drainages; Canadian Atlantic Islands
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "Ultimately, a better understanding of the environmental and genetic mechanisms responsible for population differences in run timing could both inform and improve conservation and management of Atlantic salmon populations."
Reviewer Comments: Study says climate variability but discusses rate of change over time between the early 1970s, mid 1980s, and early 1990s.

Study Area: major watersheds in western Montana (United States of America), northern Idaho (United States of America), and southern British Columbia
Detailed Change in Response Variable: depress population abundance, increase population variability, and decrease population growth rate
Freshwater Ecoregion: Upper Saskatchewan; Columbia Glaciated; Columbia Unglaciated; Upper Missouri
Major Habitat Type: Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands; Temperate upland rivers
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "other stressors - especially invasive fishes - are immediate threats that can be addressed by proactive management actions. Therefore, climate-adaptation strategies for freshwater biodiversity should consider existing abiotic and biotic stressors, some of which provide potential and realized opportunity for conservation of freshwater biodiversity in a warming world." "...Programmes to control invasive fishes will be an important climate adaptation and mitigation strategy...management efforts targeting existing human stressors - whether invasive species or land use - may be the most economical and effective climate-adaptation strategies."
Management Recommendations: Minimize other anthropogenic stressors; Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats
Reviewer Comments: Interactive effects of climate, invasive species, and land use change.

Detailed Change in Response Variable: Number of lakes predicted with high relative abundance of largemouth bass
Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes; Upper Mississippi
Major Habitat Type: Large lakes; Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "Predicting lakes or lake types that are most likely to support desired species now and into the future will enable more effective resource allocation. Furthermore, by predicting the success of two recreationally important fish species simultaneously, managers can perhaps shift resources and target outreach efforts to focus on the species most likely to succeed in a given lake (in most cases, largemouth bass)...management strategies designed to sustain and protect walleye could focus on these resilient lakes. Alternatively, managers can identify lakes where management actions such as walleye stocking will likely be the only option for providing a walleye fishery."
Management Recommendations: Protect refugial populations and/or habitats; Prioritize populations based on vulnerability; Modify fishing regulations; Alter stocking practices

Detailed Change in Response Variable: Number of lakes predicted to lose, maintain, gain, or never support successful walleye recruitment
Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes; Upper Mississippi
Major Habitat Type: Large lakes; Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands

Alternatively, managers can identify lakes where management actions such as walleye stocking will likely be the only option for providing a walleye fishery."
Management Recommendations: Protect refugial populations and/or habitats; Prioritize populations based on vulnerability; Modify fishing regulations; Alter stocking practices

Date Range of Study: 1990 [30-year average representing 1976-2005] and 2085 [18 global climate models (GCMs) for Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) 8.5 for the year 2085]
Detailed Change in Response Variable: high species turnover dominated by species loss
Freshwater Ecoregion: Southwestern Australia; Pilbara; Kimberley; Paleo; Arafura - Carpentaria; Lake Eyre Basin; Eastern Coastal Australia; Murray - Darling; Bass Strait Drainages
Major Habitat Type: Temperate coastal rivers; Tropical and subtropical coastal rivers; Xeric freshwaters and endorheic (closed) basins
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "While freshwater systems globally are subject to immediate and pressing threats from anthropogenic land and water use, management interventions addressing these pressures need to be considered within the context of climate change."
Reviewer Comments: 194 fish species included in study.

Freshwater Ecoregion: Upper Mississippi; Teays - Old Ohio
Major Habitat Type: Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands; Temperate upland rivers
Management Recommendations - Detailed: No formal management recommendation

Detailed Change in Response Variable: increased larval growth rates and improved recruitment
Freshwater Ecoregion: Central & Western Europe
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "observed changes in fish community emphasize the need to continue monitoring environmental parameters and fisheries to gather more accurate data to explain the fish community succession and better understand interactions between global and local anthropogenic forcing."
Reviewer Comments: Combined interactions among stressors (phosphorus concentration and climate warming).

Study Area: 10 river sites across the species range from Northern Indian Lake, Manitoba, to Indian River, Florida
Detailed Change in Response Variable: increases in growth (measure via number of days suporting growth) in the northern parts of the species' natural range and declines or extirpation in the south
Freshwater Ecoregion: Southern Hudson Bay; English - Winnipeg Lakes; Florida Peninsula
Major Habitat Type: Large lakes; Temperate coastal rivers; Tropical and subtropical coastal rivers
Management Recommendations - Detailed: No formal management recommendation
Reviewer Comments: Experimental-based projection model used.

Detailed Change in Response Variable: delayed, shorter migration runs with cooler SST, and sea surface temperatures have cooled during the study period
Freshwater Ecoregion: Alaskan Coastal
Management Recommendations - Detailed: "Identifying the importance of ocean conditions and temperature in the staging area provides another factor that could inform in-season management. For instance, a shorter duration of the migration would reduce opportunities for subsistence harvest. The importance of river temperature highlights the sensitivity of this system and emphasizes that future decisions on human activities within the watershed will need to assess any impacts on river temperature.

Study Area: Wenatchee River, Columbia River basin, Washington, United States of America
Climate Change Driver: temperature and flow modeled using hydrology models/4 GCMS
Detailed Change in Response Variable: 0-7% decrease in spawner abundance, 3/4 models predicted 4-7% decrease. Increased scour from increases in high-discharge events during in-gravel period reduced spawner abundance by an additional 15%. The 25% increase in mortality during the in-gravel period was artificially set by the researchers due to an inability to directly include in-gravel mortality.
Freshwater Ecoregion: Alaska & Canada Pacific Coastal; Columbia Glaciated; Columbia Unglaciated
Major Habitat Type: Temperate coastal rivers; Temperate floodplain rivers and wetlands; Temperate upland rivers
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Restore habitats to mitigate effects of climate change for vulnerable populations. Specifically, restore upland and riparian forests and reduce anthropogenic impervious area.  From text: "reforestation and reducing riparian grazing can promote riparian forests that shade stream channels as well as reduce runoff, leading to less erosion and reduced flashiness of discharge in response to precipitation  "
Management Recommendations: Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats
Reviewer Comments: Clarified climate driver, clarified response variable.  Added quoted text describing management actions given the researchers suggest that only small changes occur in abundance due to climate change, but those management actions that are important for habitat restoration will also lower temperature and reduce flashiness, increase resilience to climate change.

Detailed Change in Response Variable: changes in habitat suitability based on species optimal and suboptimal growth temperature requirements varied with region, time period, and climate forcing scenario used.
Freshwater Ecoregion: Laurentian Great Lakes
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Protect land cover types that promote groundwater recharge, preserve riparian vegetation, maintain connectivity, remove dams. Modify fishing regulations to protect fish, especially during thermally stressful periods. Maintain diversity of life stages, genetic stocks, etc.
Management Recommendations: Manage flows; Restore aquatic and associated terrestrial habitats; Restore connectivity; Modify fishing regulations

Study Area: Bear Lake, on the border of northern Utah and Idaho

Detailed Change in Response Variable: general decrease in CPUE and recruitment with reduced cobble availability due to reduced lake depth caused by climate-driven drought. Younger age classes (age 0 and 1) were more affected by reduced habitat availability.
Freshwater Ecoregion: Bonneville
Management Recommendations - Detailed: Preventative management strategies to increase resilience to climate change and drought, including adaptive management, long-term planning, creation of littoral habitat

Reviewer Comments: Paper is about how the reduction of littoral habitats due to climate induced-droughts limits spawning habitat available for the sculpin to spawn (need cobble). This limits recruitment as the sculpin need to mature to age 2 to spawn and under duress they cannot do this. Increased predation of nests as nest habitat is reduced (species interactions). Sculpin is listed as a vulnerable species in Utah and is native to Utah. Sculpin is important prey species for native Utah Bonneville cutthroat trout and non-native lake trout
